title: Susan B. Anthony Papers: Daybook and Diaries, 1856-1906; Diaries; 1872

entries.fullText:
On Pullman Car. American Union Pacific
R.R. left Ogden 3 P.M. Thursday Dec
28th having waited there from Wednesday 27th
8 A.M. -- on way home, Rochester, N.Y.
from six months in California, Oregon,
Wash. Ter. & Nevada. 6 months of
constant travel full 8000 miles --
108 lectures -- The year's work -- full
13000 miles, travel -- 170 meetings
Gross receipts
Expenses -
Nett put to debts for Revolution

Hon. A. A. Sargent -- wife,
Ellen C. -- daughter Ella & Lizzie --
Son George and lad Joseph
Mitchell in charge to Washington, D.C
--Member of Congress -- & W. S. Senator elect
for California -- -- Paid at
Laramie all last night -- breakfast
this A.M. at R.R. Hotel--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is on her way home to Rochester, NY after six months of constant travel, 108 lectures, and 170 meetings. She mentions her expenses and debts for Revolution. She also lists the people she is traveling with and the places she has visited.

entries.fullText:
J. H: Hayford - Ed Laramie
Sentinel - told us of Wyoming Legislature’s
bill to rescind Suffrage Law
- 4 Repub's in Council voted against
repeal & 5 Dems for - 1 Repub.
offerred $1000. to change vote for - but
was saved from accepting bribe by being
invited & dined by the women of Laramie
In the Assembly the 3 (three) Repubs
voted against - & every Democrat for
Great glory that no back
track is taken - Gov. Campbells
veto is grand -

About 11 A.M. we started
on reached an immense snow
Cut - tremendous wind - about
5 miles west of Sherman -
our steepest grade - about 2 P.M.
there stuck or stopped under
snow shed till dark - over
100 men shovelling in front
Dined - Mr. Sargent offering
Roast Turkey, bread & jelly, Spice
Cake & excellent cup of Tea -
at dark 5 P.M. the wind
& snow blowing terrificaly - bright sky
entries.summaryText: Journal entry about the Wyoming Legislature's bill to rescind Suffrage Law, the train journey, and dining with Mr. Sargent.

entries.fullText:
7 1/2 miles west of Sherman
Tuesday- Breafast at 8 1/2
- Cold Roast Turkey, Dried Salmon,
Bread & Butter & Jelly & Soda Crackers
-(The Fish & Crackers - rations
from the W. P. Provisions Car-)
The tea excellent - Mr. S. making it
over spirit lamp - - They finish
theirs with condensed milk - I mine
with two big lumps of sugar -
- This A.M. the sun bright & very
little wind - but no report
from the front -
Five days from Ogden - at 3
this P.M. - The Train in front of
us is now 10 days from Ogden - we
overtook them - This is indeed
a fearful ordeal - fastened here in these
snow banks mid way the continent & at
the very highest point of Rocky Mountains
full 8,000 feet above level of the sea -
snow melted for Engine Boiler & Car
water tanks - Passengers furnished with
soda crackers & dried fish - a train loaded with
entries.summaryText: Journal entry about breakfast, the train journey, and being stuck in the snow mid-way through the continent.

entries.fullText:
Wind gone down - perfectly
calm & bright sunshine -
Ernest Melliss eldest son of D.M. Melliss
New York - came in car - he is
on train that left Ogden on
Friday Dec 22 _ hence twelve days
out _ his brother Norman with him
_ how it revives The Revolution experiences
and train & Wall street gossip.
Stood Still in the snow shed until
noon- moved on to Sherman about
6 P.M._ Mr Sargent went
out prospecting for supper-
but decided best chances at our
own basket - he added potatoes
which were roasted in top of stove
& were indeed most delicious -
All this day & 3 miles more-
In Sacramento- had court
women jurors - Judge Mitchell
Presided - woman carried in verdict
written by him - Stupid women
will they ever deem to think & act for themselves
entries.summaryText: Ernest Melliss, eldest son of D.M. Melliss, came in car. The train was stuck in a snow shed until noon and moved on to Sherman about 6 P.M. Mr Sargent went out prospecting for supper but decided best chances at their own basket. In Sacramento, there was a court with women jurors and Judge Mitchell presided.

entries.fullText:
coal behind us - hence no danger
of actual suffering -
Mr Sargent- Major Elliott, Mr
Mitchell & others walked the 7 1/2
miles to Sherman - returned about
dusk _ Old man drove them back with
two ponies & two dogs _ Train had moved
up 4 1/2 miles to Dale Creek Bridge _
long & frail looking Tressle work - here
we remained all night - train
drawn under a long snow shed
& hence very close - almost suffocating
taking smoke of engine & rare atmosphere
together- The winds
swept up most furiously -
no hope of getting beyond
Sherman tomorrow -
entries.summaryText: Mr Sargent, Major Elliott, Mr Mitchell, and others walked 7 1/2 miles to Sherman and returned about dusk. The train had moved up 4 1/2 miles to Dale Creek Bridge. They remained all night under a long snow shed and the winds swept up most furiously. There was no hope of getting beyond Sherman tomorrow.

entries.fullText:
Seven days out from Ogden at 3 P.M. -

Daylight found us at
Sherman still - never moved
on until 1 P.M. - here we
found another train ahead
of us - hence we now
have four passenger trains
in line pushing for Cheyenne
hoping to reach there to night.

At Buford Station - first station
east of Sherman we met
passenger train going west,
3 days out from Omaha.
Here Col. Hooker left us &
took westward bound train back
- fearing he could not get back
to California this winter if he
went through to Des Moines -
- Passengers say they have been two
weeks from St Louis.

Visited Train no. 2. this A.M.
& found the young Mellis at breakfast -
Norman grown almost as tall as
his brother Ernest -.

About half way from
Buford to Granite Canyon -
snow plow got off track and
one wheel of [front train] sleeper on train ahead of us
broke - so a dead stand
still again for hours - utterly
discouraging - due next
Wednesday the 10th six days
to our Washington Convention.

Arrived Granite Canyon
at dark - staid there all
night - from Sherman
to Granite Canyon in
one day
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her train journey from Ogden to Granite Canyon, mentioning the different stations and trains they encountered, as well as the people she met along the way.

entries.fullText:
Granite Canyon -
bright & beautiful -
started off about 9 A.M.

Cheyenne about 11:30 -
Little Georgie [?]
asked his papa to walk
over bridge to the town
- he fell broke his arm
above wrist -. Mrs S.
after watching the painful
process of setting the bone
fainted. I called at
Mrs Posts - She went to
depot with me, - saw
Church Howe, Gov. Campbell
Mr. Arnold & others - joy
that woman suffrage was & is
loved in the territory -
at 1:30 - train was off -
& at first class yard - & oh what
joy in all faces - Georgie not in harm
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Granite Canyon and Cheyenne, where she witnesses a boy breaking his arm and faints after watching the bone being set. She also meets with various people who support woman suffrage.

entries.fullText:
Pleasant weather -
arrived Omaha at 3 P.M.
- met Geo P Bemis - Julia not
able to come to depot - Found
letters from D.R. with pass to Leavenworth -.
Saying he had also passes
for me to Fort Scott, Chicago -
- dreadfully cut down that it is
impossible for me to go - unless
I give up Washington the 10th

Brother Merritt no better -
wife Mary L. writes he has
not been able to straiten
himself up in three months -
But for this snow bound
delay - I should have gone down [?] taken
him to Rochester with me -
Letter from sister Mary - all
well there - Mother very feeble -
but not suffering - But,
my hard work is to give
up Leavenworth & Fort Scott
- my fate to sacrifice love & affection.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrives in Omaha and receives letters from D.R. with passes to Leavenworth and Fort Scott, but is unable to go due to prior commitments. She also receives news that her brother Merritt is not doing well.

entries.fullText:
Sunday - Little George's
Sargents arm getting on
finely. Two more
making in all six
overland trains joined
in our train at Council
Bluff + immensely heavy
+ only one feeble engine.
Sleeping car wheels on
fire & at last axle broke
& car left at [?]
Junction.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about Little George's and Sargent's arm, trains joining in at Council Bluff, and a sleeping car catching fire and breaking down at [?].

entries.fullText:
Chicago - arrived 3 A.M.
went Aunt A. [?]. [?]
sons. had nice chat -
Then to here till 7 A.M.
then breakfast & to
Fort Wayne Depot. - Found
Sargents not going [?]
A.M.- train no sleeping
car. My valise and satchel
checked to somebody else
check 4591. B. Master
promised to right
but Sargent insisted on
our looking after it at
Council Bluff. Just my
fate when men helps me
but good luck that
it was not my trunk.
Levaton Otle - Cary [?]
[?] remark [?]
hand
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrives in Chicago, has a nice chat with Aunt A.'s sons, and experiences trouble with her luggage being checked to the wrong person and Sargent insisting they look after it at Council Bluff.

entries.fullText:
Passed Pittsburg about
2 A.M. - breakfasted
At top of Allegheny Mts -
Altona-
seems most
lovely - but on small
scale with California-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony passed through Pittsburg and Allegheny Mts on her way to Altona, which she found lovely but on a small scale compared to California.

entries.fullText:
Constitutional Conventions
to be held in
Ohio - Wisconson
Pennsylvania and New York
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony notes that Constitutional Conventions will be held in Ohio, Wisconson, Pennsylvania, and New York in 1879.

Went to the Arlington Hotel
Mrs. Sargeant and family also -
found Mrs Stanton there
Mrs [?], Mrs. P W James

entries.fullText:
TUESDAY, JANUARY 16, 1872

I have been thinking that I would make a record of the events of my life for my own more ready reference and for the information of my family. It seems to me that the incidents of my early life are important only as they are related to those of later life and that in writing of things long past it is not necessary to enter into minute details. My birthplace was South Adams, a town in the western part of Massachusetts, near the New York line. My father, Daniel Anthony, was a cotton manufacturer in that town and in the neighboring town of Hoosick Falls, just over the line in New York State. My mother was Lucy Read. I was the second child in a family of seven. My earliest recollection is of hearing a sermon read by my father in the Congregational Church in which he was then interested. I was then between three and four years old. My next recollection is of walking with my mother and older sister Sally from the little old red schoolhouse up the hill to the new and larger one which replaced it. I was then between four and five years old. I remember that I was much pleased with the new schoolhouse and especially with the stove, which was so high that I could stand erect in the oven. I was then so small that the top of the desk was above my shoulders. I could not write, but I listened to the writing lesson and envied the children who were able to make the beautiful letters. I was then between five and six years old. I remember that I was very much interested in the geography lesson and in the maps and that I learned to read quite readily. I was then between six and seven years old. I remember that I was very much interested in the geography lesson and in the maps and that I learned to read quite readily. I was then between six and seven years old. I remember that I was very much interested in the geography lesson and in the maps and that I learned to read quite readily. entries.fullText:
FRIDAY, JANUARY 19, 1872

I have been reading the morning paper. The President has sent to the Senate the nomination of Frederick Douglass as one of the Commissioners of Santo Domingo. This is a movement in the right direction. Mr. Douglass is eminently fitted for the position and his appointment would be a credit to the administration. I hope the Senate will confirm the nomination.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony comments on the nomination of Frederick Douglass as a Commissioner of Santo Domingo.

entries.fullText: Took train to Leavnworth - arrived at 4 P. M -
entries.summaryText: Took train to Leavnworth.

entries.fullText: Called at St. Louis to see Mrs. Minor Virginia L. Minor
entries.summaryText: Visited Mrs. Minor in St. Louis.

entries.fullText: Liberal Republican Convention - Laura De[?]Gordon & self urged W. S. Plank - but got no favor
entries.summaryText: Attended Liberal Republican Convention and urged W. S. Plank.

entries.fullText: Cincinnati - O. Lib. Repub. Con -
entries.summaryText: Attended Liberal Republican Convention in Cincinnati.

entries.fullText:
Cincinnati - Liberal
Repub. Con. - nominated
Greeley - & G. Brown -
Gratz
Left Cincinnatti on night
train - Such a jam could not
get a sleeping car - So sat
up to Clevelans restive Sat A.M.
took sleeper
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left Cincinnati and took a train to Cleveland, where she had to sit up due to the lack of sleeping cars.

entries.fullText:
Spent Sunday at home -
busy day chatting - & at 5.20
took sleeping car to New York -
Toured elegant new
Crystal Palace Depot there
perfectly delightful -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spent the day at home and then took a sleeping car to New York, where she visited the Crystal Palace Depot.

entries.fullText:
Took sleeping car at
Cleveland & slept to
Buffalo - arrived Rochester
at 5.20 - found all well
& slept in my own little bed
This belongs to Saturdy
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony took a sleeping car from Cleveland to Buffalo and arrived in Rochester, where she slept in her own bed.

entries.fullText:
New York - 7.30 A.M
Breakfasted Mrs.
Murrays &i called Mrs. Phelps
- heard Woodhull's move to
blackmail the women - went
Westmoreland Hotel - took possessn
Parlors - then Tenalfy & bro't Mrs
Stanton over to the Hotel -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in New York and had breakfast with Mrs. Murrays and Mrs. Phelps. She then went to the Westmoreland Hotel and met with Woodhull, Mrs. Stanton, and others.

entries.fullText:
Westmoreland - Woodhull Party -
Banks, Davis, Allen &c met Parlors -
claimed right to possess the
meeting - told them it the women Suffrage
- Evident they were bound to try
their strength & Strategy -
Hooker arriving this P.M-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attended a meeting at the Westmoreland Hotel with Woodhull, Banks, Davis, Allen, and others. They discussed their right to possess the meeting and their strategy for women's suffrage.

entries.fullText:
Mrs T. & self wrote
Resolutions & Platform -
There never was such
a foolish muddle - all come
of Mrs S. consulting with & conceding
to Woodhull - & call'g
Peoples Con - instead of W. S. Con.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and Mrs. T. wrote resolutions and a platform, but there was confusion due to Mrs. S. consulting with and conceding to Woodhull, and calling it the Peoples Con instead of the W. S. Con.

entries.fullText:
- National W.S. Convention
at Strenway Hall Head
Quarters at Westmoreland Hotel
- The Woodhull Co. bound to take
possession of the Convention - but
failed - & left in disgust -
entries.summaryText: National W.S. Convention at Strenway Hall Head Quarters at Westmoreland Hotel. The Woodhull Co. bound to take possession of the Convention - but failed - & left in disgust -

entries.fullText:
- National Convention - again
- small audience - the
fiasco perfect - from calling
Peoples Convention - Never
did Mrs Stanton do so foolish
a thing - all came near
being lost - Mrs A.S. Duniway
came in. P.M. - 1 or days from Portland
entries.summaryText: National Convention - again - small audience - the fiasco perfect - from calling Peoples Convention - Never did Mrs Stanton do so foolish a thing - all came near being lost - Mrs A.S. Duniway came in. P.M. - 1 or days from Portland

entries.fullText:
Mrs Lozier takes Mrs Duniway
to her home - Jones,
Duniway and [?] [?]
over to Tenafly - I never
was so hurt with folly
of Stanton
entries.summaryText: Mrs Lozier takes Mrs Duniway to her home - Jones, Duniway and [?] [?] over to Tenafly - I never was so hurt with folly of Stanton

entries.fullText:
X Pleasant day - but -
sad to me - Our
movement as such is so
demoralised by the letting go the
helm of ship to Woodhull - though
we rescued it - it was as by a hairs
breadth escape -
entries.summaryText: X Pleasant day - but - sad to me - Our movement as such is so demoralised by the letting go the helm of ship to Woodhull - though we rescued it - it was as by a hairs breadth escape -

entries.fullText:
Went back to Westmoreland
with Jones -
Trotted all over City
with Jones and Duniway
entries.summaryText: Went back to Westmoreland with Jones - Trotted all over City with Jones and Duniway

entries.fullText:
Mrs Jones & Duniway
saw Greely - but, got no
comfort from him - he is
perfectly stolid - Gordon,
Wendt & Blake all had
talk
entries.summaryText: Mrs Jones & Duniway saw Greely - but, got no comfort from him - he is perfectly stolid - Gordon, Wendt & Blake all had talk

entries.fullText:
Mrs. Jones left for home. at
Mrs. Loeziers found Telegram
that Asa Anthony was dead -
looked after business at Johnstons,
dined at Geo Culdwells & took
sleeping car at 8 P.M. for Rochester
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Jones leaves, Asa Anthony is dead, and travel to Rochester.

entries.fullText:
Reached home at 10 A.M.,
- got washed and dressed - &
dined & went with Gula, May
Mother, & Aaron to funeral of
Asa Anthony - Gen, Taylor -
Geo, W. Clark & Eliza I [?] spoke
beautiful day.
entries.summaryText: Funeral of Asa Anthony.

entries.fullText:
Went to Miss Sorson's - no
chance for dress making for
a whole week. Called at
May Hallowells - talked
over sickness & death of her
father Isaac Port-
entries.summaryText: Visits to Miss Sorson and May Hallowells.

entries.fullText:
Mother & self dined at Asa's
Daniel Anthonys - Huldah,
Matilda Anthony & Sarah H were
there - Dr. Requer is trying
his luck on my teeth again -
+.
entries.summaryText: Dinner at Asa's Daniel Anthonys and a visit to the dentist.

entries.fullText:
Rainy day - wrote seven
letters. Sister May & self
called at Amy Posts - she
looks lonely enough, with her
Isaac gone - May & William
there - talk on Woodhull Part -
entries.summaryText: Rainy day, letter writing, and a visit to Amy Posts.

entries.fullText:
Home - Woodhull Paper
comes freighted with glorious
triumph - Stanton, Hooker &
Anthony- lost sight of altogether.
- mere single births of her great
bundle -
entries.summaryText: Reading the Woodhull Paper and mentions of Stanton, Hooker, and Anthony.

entries.fullText:
At home letters from
Hooker - showing that she
is bound to throw herself
back onto Woodhull's power
again - so she will again
need the Lord's special help to
rescue her
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives letters from Hooker about Woodhull's power.

entries.fullText:
Woodhull's paper came - she
wheels everything into her
service - no denunciation
simply calls us too slow -
To Dentist Requa in
P.M - but the job a tee
total failure - as have here
every one of the year -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives Woodhull's paper and goes to the dentist.

entries.fullText:
Went to Miss Larson's
early - thence to Wm & Mary
Hallowells to dinner - then
home to tea & with sister Mary
to workingmens Hall to hear Mrs
B.A. Lockwood for Woodhull Party
- compelled to express my dissent.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a dinner and a speech by Mrs. B.A. Lockwood for the Woodhull Party.

entries.fullText:
Auburn - M. C. Wright - to meet
Mrs. M. Joslyn Gage — left
home 7.30 - reached Auburn at 11-
Mrs Gage at 1 P.M. weather
perfectly delightful - trees all in
bloom & most fragrant - most
cordial reception -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony goes to Auburn to meet with M. C. Wright and Mrs. M. Joslyn Gage.

entries.fullText:
Ms. W. G. & self took note - &
called at Eliza's new house - has
fine green house & grapery - &
foundation of house being laid -
wrote up constitution - & settled
upon list of officers -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Eliza's new house and writes up a constitution.

entries.fullText:
At Ms. M.C. Wrights Auburn
chatted all the A. M. - dined
at 4 P.M. with daughter Eliza.
(Munson Osborn) & delightful chat
over Yosemite & California -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends time with Ms. M.C. Wright and Eliza, discussing Yosemite and California.

entries.fullText:
Left Auburn with Mrs Gage then
Syracuse to Rochester - 8:30 A.M.
Had to wait to 2:40 P.M. train -
Had delightful visit the Wrights
Arrived home at 6 P.M.
found brother D. R. here since
Sunday A.M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Auburn to Rochester with Mrs Gage and has a delightful visit with the Wrights.

entries.fullText:
Sent Sister Annie 3 1/2 - [?] -
Burt shoes - from Pratts - $7. -
Maud no 7 hose day no. 8.
Brother D. R. left for
Kansas on 9.20 P.M. train
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony sends shoes to her sister and her brother D. R. leaves for Kansas.

entries.fullText: Home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is at home.

entries.fullText: Home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is at home.

entries.fullText: Home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is at home.

entries.fullText: Home
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is at home.

entries.fullText: Took 8:10 Erie train via Lehigh Valley R.R. to Philadelphia - arrived at 11 P.M. - found Miss M. A. Thomson waiting for me - the scenery on route lovely - in [?y] California -
entries.summaryText: Susan travels to Philadelphia and meets Miss M. A. Thomson.

entries.fullText: Miss Gibbons - Press Reporter interviewed me - this A.M. paper had report - went to E. M. Davis Office - met sundry friends there - H.B. Blackwell among them - Sarah Pugh came into city & stopped [?] me -
entries.summaryText: Susan is interviewed by Miss Gibbons and meets with friends including H.B. Blackwell and Sarah Pugh.

entries.fullText: Raining all thru day- National Republican Convention Philadelphia - immense gathering - Academy of Music - Radical club meeting at Davis office - Blackwell declared he was a republican anyhow - W.S. or no W.S.
entries.summaryText: Susan attends the National Republican Convention in Philadelphia.

entries.fullText: Met Mrs Livermore at Davis office - she went with me to the [Co?] -Reporters gallery- just missed Platform Com's report - with its woman suffrage splinter of a plank in it -
entries.summaryText: Susan meets with Mrs Livermore and attends the [Co?] -Reporters gallery.

entries.fullText: Sara Pugh called with me at A.E.D's house - to surprise found her home - — not the old time greeting - but cold, cold - she charges me with betraying her confidence - Linemann & Hanaford - it is a plot of Whitelaw Reids to break her off from me
entries.summaryText: Susan visits A.E.D's house with Sara Pugh and has a tense encounter with A.E.D, who accuses her of betraying her confidence. There is also mention of a plot by Whitelaw Reids to break Sara off from Susan.

entries.fullText:
Sarah Pugh put note in
my hand, it contained $90. to go
to see Mrs Stanton - so I took
8:20 train with S.D. Gordon &
found Mrs Stanton at 2:30 P.M.
& chatted over Convention
and things in general
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony meets with Sarah Pugh and S.D. Gordon to visit Mrs. Stanton and discuss the Convention.

entries.fullText:
at Tenafly -wrote World
article - "Baltimore [W?]"
in June 19th paper -
Amelia gone - only Nannie
left- she is a jewel of a girl.
Hattie and Neil home - [Gatt?]
and Ritt over for Sunday only
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes an article for the World and spends time with family and friends in Tenafly.

entries.fullText:
Called at Mrs Phelps & World
office and then to 12:30 train -
met Robert Purvisat Bristol
and went to his house - wife very ill
hemorrage of lungs - learned from him
that A. E. D. lets Susan tell him & others
that I fabricated terrible charges against S. [?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Mrs. Phelps and the World office before meeting with Robert Purvis in Bristol to discuss fabricated charges against her.

entries.fullText:
Lovely and cool day-
Sister Mary and self Unitarian
church - [?] - Liberals
really believe more - not less
than the orthodox - mother
and self reading V.A. Staples
biography & sermons - sad - beautiful
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends church with her sister and reads V.A. Staples' biography and sermons with her mother.

entries.fullText:
Lovely rain all day -
Wendell, Mother and self pumped
out cistern full of hard water
& cleaned it - & rained enough to [?]
Letters from Hooker and Jones -
wrote to Hooker, Jones Stanton &
Aaron & Gula-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends the day cleaning and receives letters from Hooker and Jones, and writes to Hooker, Jones, Stanton, Aaron, and Gula.

entries.fullText:
Hooker letter said Mrs Stanton had
not forwarded her letters to me
because of criticisms of me
in answer to my criticisms of
her - sent her by Stanton - &
Stanton did not wish me
to know she had opposed them.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives a letter from Hooker stating that Mrs. Stanton did not forward her letters due to criticisms of Susan, which were sent by Stanton without Mrs. Stanton's approval.

entries.fullText:
Sarah Jane Hyatt Nickels, 4
daughters and nurse - girl -
dinner at Hannahs -
on way home letter from
Aaron written Saturday night
10-22nd
entries.summaryText: Dinner at Hannah's with Sarah Jane Hyatt Nickels and received a letter from Aaron.

entries.fullText:
Letter from Gula - very
hot weather out there as
well as here -
Maggie came down and I
went with her to Mrs Harris
dress maker -
entries.summaryText: Received a letter from Gula and went with Maggie to Mrs. Harris' dress maker.

entries.fullText:
Cousin Rosa T Anthony
of Leavenworth called and [?]
going to St. Paul's to spend
the summer with her
Georgie - Mrs Kate
Blackford dined with us
& Mrs Wollcott & niece called -
entries.summaryText: Visited by Cousin Rosa T Anthony and had dinner with Mrs. Kate Blackford. Also visited by Mrs. Wollcott and niece.

entries.fullText:
May, Mrs Baker and others spending
day at Mrs Hughes - Pittsford-
called at Mary Hallowells -
Hannah & self walked
to Liberty Pole looking for strawberries -
entries.summaryText: Visited Mrs. Hughes and Mary Hallowells and went looking for strawberries at Liberty Pole.

entries.fullText:
Hannah and self walked
in broiling sun to Plymouth
Church -Bartlett ill so
a stranger gave out husks -
wrote Gula and Aaron
entries.summaryText: Went to Plymouth Church and wrote letters to Gula and Aaron.

entries.fullText:
Gula 54 years old to day
letter from Mrs M. J. Gage-
letter from Aaron & Gula
entries.summaryText: Received letters from Mrs. M. J. Gage, Aaron, and Gula on Gula's 54th birthday.

entries.fullText:
Hattie [?'s] 2nd child - daughter here -
John Cochran says he is sorry
Cincinnatti did not
adopt women suf.
entries.summaryText: Hattie's daughter is born and John Cochran expresses regret about Cincinnati not adopting women's suffrage.

entries.fullText:
Letter from Aaron - written
Sunday 30th June - they going
Fort Scott this week -
Maggie took me to Ellis'
carnival - big sell - though
music good -
entries.summaryText: Aaron is going to Fort Scott and Maggie takes Susan to a carnival at Ellis'.

entries.fullText:
Rochester - at home all day
Maggie & Harry and Grand Pa
Baker took Aunt Mary to see
the children's dinner- I
was in Kansas two years ago
to day - now Gula and Aaron at
Fort Scott to day
entries.summaryText: Susan spends the day at home in Rochester while Maggie, Harry, and Grand Pa Baker take Aunt Mary to see the children's dinner. Susan reflects on being in Kansas two years ago and notes that Gula and Aaron are in Fort Scott.

entries.fullText:
Spent day with niece
Maggie who 11 [?] of
cherries and 12 of strawberries
- she moves on so steadily
and accomplishes so much more
than it seems possible -
letter from Aaron & Gula -
entries.summaryText: Susan spends the day with her niece Maggie, who impresses her with her productivity. Susan receives a letter from Aaron and Gula.

entries.fullText:
Took 8:10 Erie Train for
Baltimore - failed get across
Phila. from North Penn depot to
the B. depot - took street car to
fare $3 - Heft Bingham House
Carrolton House
entries.summaryText: Susan takes a train from Erie to Baltimore but has trouble getting across Philadelphia and ends up taking a street car for $3. She stays at the Bingham House and Carrolton House.

entries.fullText:
Philadelphia - Breakfast at
Bingham House - then Miss
Thomson's - Bound over till
Monday 8:30 - great shame
entries.summaryText: Susan has breakfast at the Bingham House in Philadelphia before going to see Miss Thomson. She is bound over until Monday at 8:30, which she considers a great shame.

entries.fullText:
Took 11 train to
Baltimore - found Mrs.
Hooker at
House - T.T. with her -
he asked private conference
with me - but never called
again -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony takes a train to Baltimore and meets with Mrs. Hooker and T.T.

entries.fullText:
Baltimore -
dreadfully hot day -
Opera House full - Mr.
but not Mrs Meriwether here -
No possible chance for house -
The Dems just Swallow
Cincinnati hoops, horns & all -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends a hot day in Baltimore and attends the Opera House, where Mr. Meriwether is present but not Mrs. Meriwether.

entries.fullText:
Baltimore - [?]
J. [?] Gordan here - all
left on 6. P. M train - a
good shower - Hooker
& self stopped at Hotel in
Philadelphia -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony meets with J. Gordan in Baltimore and later travels to Philadelphia with Mrs. Hooker.

entries.fullText:
Took 8.30 train [?]
for Rochester - Mrs Hooker
for New Haven -
Arrived at 11 - night
met brother & Mother,
we walked from Depot -
Erie Depot
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony takes a train to Rochester with Mrs. Hooker and later meets with her brother and mother.

entries.fullText:
[Gula & Aaron visited
McLeans at Batavia -]
entries.summaryText: Gula and Aaron visit the McLeans in Batavia.

entries.fullText:
[Abigail & Mary McLean
Maxwell spent day here]
entries.summaryText: Abigail and Mary McLean Maxwell spend the day with Susan B. Anthony.

entries.fullText: SUNDAY, July 14, 1872.
MONDAY 15

Mrs M. Joslyn Gage
came - to prepare address
to women - to work for
the Repub. Party, because
of its recognition of Women

TUESDAY 16
entries.summaryText: Mrs M. Joslyn Gage came to prepare an address to women to work for the Republican Party because of its recognition of Women.

entries.fullText: WEDNESDAY, JULY 17,1872.
THURSDAY 18

Mrs Stanton says
get the American W.S.
women to sign our address
but - it is too late a suggestion
- already it is sent
off to association [?]
FRIDAY 19
entries.summaryText: Mrs Stanton suggested to get the American W.S. women to sign their address, but it was too late as it was already sent off to the association.

entries.fullText:
Mrs. Gage went home - the
address in A.M. Democrat &
P.M. Express with good Editorials
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Gage went home.

entries.fullText:
Sister Mary left for
Saratoga Teachers Convention
entries.summaryText: Sister Mary left for Saratoga Teachers Convention.

entries.fullText:
It is a powerful & highly
respectable championship
- the first that any political
Party has taken hold of it - hitherto
we have rejoiced over accession of every
renowned & good reputed champion
of individuals - now it is over the accession
of the good will of the largest &
most [high hand of ?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about a political party taking hold of a powerful and highly respectable championship.

entries.fullText:
Frank B Ward & wife
Melissa McLean & [Mar???]
McLean - daughters of Uncle
Louis called -
entries.summaryText: Frank B Ward, Melissa McLean, and Mar??? (daughters of Uncle Louis) called.

entries.fullText:
Expected Aaron & Girls -
but did not come - Mr
Ward & McLean girls dined
with us at Hannahs & took
tea - Maggie & George
[came down?] M. dreadfully
disappointed -
entries.summaryText: Aaron and his girls were expected but did not come. Mr. Ward and McLean girls dined with Susan B. Anthony and took tea. Maggie and George also came down but M. was dreadfully disappointed.

entries.fullText:
Maggie down- but
no Pa & Ma- fair
pretty long-

FRIDAY 2
No Aaron & Gula - Cousin
Mary Clark came after
dinner- Maggie &
babies down after tea.

SATURDAY 3
Gula and Aaron returned
after almost seven weeks absence
in good health & spirits- all
happy to see them home - especially
niece Maggie- Mary Clark
left for Phila
entries.summaryText: Maggie is down, but Pa and Ma are not there. Cousin Mary Clark visits and Gula and Aaron return home.

entries.fullText:
Telegram R.J. Hinton to go
to Wash. to consult Union
Cong. Repub. Com. on woman's
campaign - answered go Monday 19th
Judge Edmunds

SATURDAY 17
No May to day- her
time is up - & Mother
quite impatient-

SUNDAY 18
Mary not home yet -
went to Office after 9 P.M. and
Mother & Aaron in bed - and
Telegraphed Hinton- must postpone
to Saturday 24th- I am very
May isn't home- I can't
leave till she comes-
entries.summaryText: R.J. Hinton is going to Washington to consult the Union Cong. Repub. Com. on the woman's campaign. May is not home yet and the plan to go to Washington is postponed.

people: Antoinette D. Blackwell & Mrs. F. J. Gage
entries.fullText: Letters, pleasant, from Antoinette D. Blackwell & Mrs. F. J. Gage-
entries.summaryText: Received pleasant letters from Antoinette D. Blackwell & Mrs. F. J. Gage.

entries.fullText: Called at Jo. Curtis- C.F. Stebbins there - wide awake for 'Phila. Splinter'- Mary C, no doubt- would be great but for his antagonism to woman suffrage.
entries.summaryText: Visited Jo. Curtis and met C.F. Stebbins who was interested in 'Phila. Splinter'. Mary C. would be great but for his opposition to woman suffrage.

entries.fullText: State Repub. Con- Women not mentioned Parker Pillsbury- did not come direct to no. 7 - simply because I forgot to say to him explicitly to do so- just him all over- always compelling everybody to go 9/10 way to meet him- Aaron took 9 P.M. train to bring Maggie home. C.F. Stebbins spent day
entries.summaryText: Attended State Repub. Con where women were not mentioned. Parker Pillsbury did not come directly to no. 7 because I forgot to tell him to do so. Aaron took 9 P.M. train to bring Maggie home. C.F. Stebbins spent the day.

entries.fullText: Very very hot- shower in P.M.- sent Frank to Hallowell to see if P. P. was there- he was- he came here about 8 & I can't get over his lack of belief in me or something - it is so disagreeable a trait in so great & good a man-
entries.summaryText: Very hot day. Sent Frank to Hallowell to see if P.P. was there. He arrived at 8 PM and I am disappointed by his lack of belief in me.

entries.fullText: P. P. to Amy Posts to dinner - between salt mackerel for breakfast & the disagreeable fact I can't get into good feeling all I can do *took tea at Hallowells with P.P. he stopped there all night*
entries.summaryText: Parker Pillsbury had dinner at Amy Posts. Had tea at Hallowells with P.P. who stayed there overnight.

entries.fullText: P.P left for Pamisville Sister Mary returned at 6 & Aaron at 9.20 P. M. Maggie & boys went direct to farm
entries.summaryText: Parker Pillsbury left for Pamisville. Sister Mary and Aaron returned. Maggie and boys went to the farm.

entries.fullText: E. Willis & Hallowells - read Antoinette B.R.'s letter to [?] on 14th Plank & Tribune - says Miss A. is agitator - but most unpolitical - & sure to defeat
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony reads a letter from Antoinette B.R. and discusses Miss A.'s political views.

entries.fullText: Sister Mary & self bought black silk - Cashimere finish Cheney Brothers American - 20 yds each - & $50. each Mr & Mrs Baker left for Nebraska 2.50 a yard! now $1. will buy just as good
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and her sister buy black silk and discuss the cost of fabric.

entries.fullText: called Amy Posts - Mrs Livermore D. Chandler - Ottawa Kan - Lecture on Motherhood &c - - fails in [?] tracing back to, cause - sent Telegram to R. J. Hinton -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a lecture on motherhood and sends a telegram to R. J. Hinton.

entries.fullText: Packed trunk to be ready to go - nothing seems clear to me - - Telegram from Hinton to go Washington -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony packs her trunk and receives a telegram from Hinton to go to Washington.

entries.fullText: Left for Washington at 10 A. M. - delayed & hindered all along - cold & rain day - [?] of Baltimore sever [?] & track up - stopped all night - & dreadfully tired -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Washington and experiences delays and bad weather.

entries.fullText: arrived Washington at 3 P.M. - - Starved & tired & sleepy - Stopped at Emma Griffing - hour lonely - no Josephine
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrives in Washington and stays with Emma Griffing, feeling lonely without Josephine.

entries.fullText:
In Washington-
Saw n. J. Hinton &
Judge Edmunds &
Mrs. Helen M. Barnard.
& much encouragement
of help-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is in Washington and meets with n. J. Hinton, Judge Edmunds, and Mrs. Helen M. Barnard, receiving much encouragement.

entries.fullText:
Left Washington at 8 P.M.
Sat up all night- no
chair or sleeping cars to be had.
Mrs. Barnard to E. Griffins
to dinner.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony leaves Washington and spends the night without a chair or sleeping car. Mrs. Barnard goes to dinner at E. Griffins.

entries.fullText:
Arrived Jersey City at 6.20.
Street car to Erie Depot - waited
till 8.20 - arrived Tenafly
9.20 - lunched - found Mrs.
Stanton wide awake- and-
left for N.Y. at 12 noon - no
Mrs. Jones- no Wilhour - no
[?] - slept Dr. Luziers
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrives in Tenafly after traveling from Washington, has lunch with Mrs. Stanton, and then leaves for N.Y. without seeing Mrs. Jones or Wilhour. She sleeps at Dr. Luziers.

people: N. J. state Repub Com. J.N. [Reaft-Leiz?]
entries.fullText:
In
New York -
Called on N. J. state Repub
Com. J.N. [Reaft-Leiz?] - &
told my plan - gave me check
of $500 - back to Tenafly
at 6 PM
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is in New York and meets with N. J. state Repub Com. J.N. [Reaft-Leiz?], who gives her a check for $500 to support her plan.

entries.fullText:
In
Tenafly
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is in Tenafly.

entries.fullText:
In
Tenafly-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is in Tenafly.

entries.fullText:
Left Ms. Martins at 8 A.M.
- found Cornell of State Report
Com. at 5th Av. Hotel - then
to Mrs. Lozier's to dinner then to
West Moreland - Mr. Jones then -
Telegraphed Lucy & I in of change
date of Rochester visits to 20th
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits various locations and telegraphs Lucy about a change of plans.

entries.fullText:
No reply from Boston - Ms.
Jones went to Dr. Lozier's -
Willie & [J?] with me
to Rochester - & [?] alone
to Chicago
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives no reply from Boston and travels to various locations.

entries.fullText:
Reached R. at 10 A.M.
found no letters or telegrams
from Boston - wrote Mrs.
Livermore confidential -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrives in R. and writes a confidential letter to Mrs. Livermore.

entries.fullText:
In R
Mrs. M.J. Gage came
at 6 P.M. - Letters &
Telegrams from [?]. [?]
& Mrs. Livermore can't speak
at Rochester - & a long sermon
from H.B.B. on [?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives letters and telegrams and hears a long sermon from H.B.B.

entries.fullText:
In R. - Mrs. G. & self
called at Mary Fish Curtis.
Catharine there - Mrs. G.
too ill - went to bed -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Mary Fish Curtis with Mrs. G. who becomes too ill to continue working.

entries.fullText:
Mrs. G. left at 4 P.M.
miserable enough - like a
fever - too ill to think
of work -
entries.summaryText: Mrs. G. leaves and is too ill to work.

entries.fullText:
Feel dragged and
disheartened from
Mrs G's visit - too [sick?] -
draws the life out of me -
wish she had strength equal
to her ambition to work
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony feels disheartened after a visit from Mrs G.

entries.fullText:
In - R.
Reuben Baker's
daughters M. & C. of Easton
Wash. Co. came to Hannahs.
Rec'd confidential reply from
Mrs. Liv. - she is counted out
with Lucy & Harry -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives a visit from Reuben Baker's daughters and a reply from Mrs. Liv.

entries.fullText:
In - Rochester
Mary Baker [?] &
Cordelia B. Dennis to Dr
Moore's - Mary Scarows cancer
in right breast - Hannah &
all dined at Aarons -
I took tea at Hallowells
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends time with friends in Rochester and visits Dr. Moore's office.

entries.fullText:
In
Rochester - Gula returned
9.30 last eve - glad enough to see
her home again - though she
seems far from well yet - Maggie
& little Harry & T. R. baby came
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is happy to have Gula back in Rochester.

entries.fullText:
Cordelia Baker left - Mary
staid. Springport Cousin David
- Anthony's wife Eliza & Cousin
Cynthia Anthony came -
Senator Roscoe Conkling spoke
this eve - 3 hours - good recital
against grief -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends time with family and attends a speech by Senator Roscoe Conkling.

entries.fullText:
Cousin Eliza left 3 P.M.
Mrs. M. F. Curits & C Stebbins
called - - letters from Celia
Burleigh & Miriam Cole
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives letters from Celia Burleigh and Miriam Cole.

entries.fullText:
In Rochester—
Everything promises
well for meeting the 20th.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is in Rochester and everything looks good for the meeting on the 20th.

entries.fullText:
In. Rochester
Mrs Stanton arrived
at 10 A.M. - Olympia Brown
at 10 evening— Mrs. J. G. Jones
passed through to Chicago—
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Stanton and Olympia Brown arrive in Rochester while Mrs. J. G. Jones passes through to Chicago.

entries.fullText:
In Rochester—
Women's Republican meeting—
Mrs Stanton & O. Brown stopped
at no 7— Mrs Gage at Hallowells—
- Immense audience - Mayor
A. C. Wilder presided—Mrs Gage
& all spoke splendidly -

[*Brother D. R's 4th child—girl—born—Susie B.*]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a Women's Republican meeting in Rochester with Mrs. Stanton, O. Brown, Mrs. Gage, and Mayor A. C. Wilder. Mrs. Gage and all speakers did a splendid job. Additionally, Susan's brother's fourth child, a girl named Susie B., was born.

entries.fullText:
In. Rochester
Mrs Stanton left on
7.20 A.M. train—Olympia, C.
F. Stebbins & Giles dined at W. H.
Hallowell's—read to them all
H. B. B.'s & Lucy's letters to Mrs
Stanton—Will not work with
Miss Anthony or the harden
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Stanton leaves Rochester while Olympia, C. F. Stebbins, and Giles dine at W. H. Hallowell's. They read letters from H. B. B. and Lucy to Mrs. Stanton and mention they will not work with Miss Anthony or the harden.

entries.fullText:
Wrote letters & worked
all day—Olympia
preached in Universalist
Church in evening—made
good impression—
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes letters and works all day while Olympia preaches at a Universalist Church in the evening and makes a good impression.

entries.fullText:
From—
Rochester on
5 P.M. Train—Olympia
Brown too—Ministers Saxe
& Mann called on Olympia—
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and Olympia Brown leave Rochester on the 5 P.M. train. Ministers Saxe and Mann also call on Olympia.

entries.fullText:
In - New York --
Olympia direct to Bridgeport -
I to Dr. Loziers - saw State &
National repub. Com's - all
right - called Mrs. Phelps, Wilhemina
Wendt & Blake - all ready for
work -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits New York and meets with State and National Republican Committees.

entries.fullText:
In - N.J.
engaged Cooper
Hall for Oct. 7th - went
over to Mrs Stantons -
found her with sever
cold - children all in
school again - & Amelia
back at the helm again
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits New Jersey and engages Cooper Hall for an event on October 7th.

entries.cityOrState: Tenafly to N. York & thence Philadelphia
entries.fullText:
From Tenafly to N. York
& thence Philadelphia -
Telegraphed Mrs. Livermore
speak at N.Y. meeting the 7th
Oct. - Miss Thomson met
me at Depot - Tea Meeting -
at 8 P.M
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Tenafly to New York and then to Philadelphia to attend a Tea Meeting.

entries.fullText:
In Philadelphia -
called on Russell Evrett -
Chair, Pa. State Repub. Com. -
Mrs Stanton to speak. Phila. Oct 2d
Wilkinson 2d - Scranton 4th -meeting
of citizen suffrage, at E. M. Davis office -
went to Lucretias at 5.20 - found
her charming as ever - though delicate
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Philadelphia and meets with Russell Evrett and Lucretias.

entries.cityOrState: Roadside - York Station - North Pa. R.R. to New York
entries.fullText:
From - Roadside - York
Station - North Pa. R.R. to New York
Lucretia Mott, Marcia M. Davis
& Belle Mott Parish drove me over
to Germantown call Sarah
Pugh - long talk with E.M. Davis -
dined Miss Thomsons -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Roadside to Germantown and has dinner with Miss Thomsons.

entries.fullText:
In
New York, - Dr. Loziers
Trunk not delivered -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is in New York and her trunk has not been delivered.

entries.fullText: State Annual meeting- took 8 A.M. train- Found Mrs Hooker at Comstocks - small meeting
entries.summaryText: Attended State Annual meeting in New Haven and met with Mrs Hooker at Comstocks.

entries.fullText: [German W. S. Meeting Turners Hall- 8 P.M. 21st St. Near Bowery-] wasted day
entries.summaryText: Attended German W. S. Meeting at Turners Hall in New York.

entries.fullText: met Mrs Stanton at Jersey City - she speaks Philadelphia this evening - Russell Errett Chairman Penn. State Repub. Com.
entries.summaryText: Met with Mrs Stanton in Jersey City and discussed her speaking engagement in Philadelphia with Russell Errett, Chairman of Penn. State Repub. Com.

entries.fullText: No entry
entries.summaryText: No entry for this date.

entries.fullText: Went to church in the morning. In the afternoon went to see Mrs. Bloomer and met Mrs. Stanton there. Had a pleasant call. Came home and wrote till tea time.
entries.summaryText: Went to church and visited Mrs. Bloomer and Mrs. Stanton.

entries.fullText: Went to Canandaigua to attend the Republican rally. Spoke in the evening at the Opera House. Had a very fine audience and spoke nearly two hours.
entries.summaryText: Attended a Republican rally in Canandaigua and spoke at the Opera House.

entries.fullText: Nothing important occurred today.
entries.summaryText: Nothing important occurred today.

entries.fullText:
Left
New York for Rochester
via Erie R.R. at 7.45-
rained all day -
ordered Wagner's sewing
machine sent to R. - Long
call at Madam Demorests - No chance
for tea trade.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left New York for Rochester via Erie R.R. and had a long call at Madam Demorests.

entries.fullText:
Arrived Rochester 11 A.M.
Found all well as usual -
but sister Gula - she has
serious lung difficulty - growing
worse - of near three years standing
Mary & self called at Dr. Sarah [Dollys?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Rochester and visited her sister and Dr. Sarah.

entries.fullText:
In -
Rochester - very pleasant
Plymouth Church with brother A.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went to Plymouth Church with her brother in Rochester.
